Yes, he does. He would have great difficulty reading such minuscule
newspaper print without them. Unlike you, who seem to have no difficulty at all.
I'm really not a dangerous criminal.

I know that. I see it in your eyes. You're a good, kind man, as I also see it in your eyes that you are not my husband. I've known from the start, but was somehow able to convince myself that you were Edward, that you had to be him. So much depended on it.
I have been trying to tell you.
Yes, I know. Bless you for not having been too harsh with me. Nor having taken advantage of a vulnerable woman. I've done a foolish thing and must heartily beg your forgiveness.
There's nothing to forgive, Georgina. I've enjoyed this short time with you. It's been very pleasant. But I shall, of course, take my leave of you tonight, before any more harm is done.
No! You cannot. You must not.
I can't stay here. What would your neighbours think? A stranger in the house while your husband is away? Your honour and reputation would be in shreds.
The neighbours can think what I want them to think, that Edward has returned from his sojourn overseas and that all is well. You must stay, for the time being at least.

I have my own life to lead, my own friends. You thank me for not having taken advantage of you, but in truth I have. I've eaten at your table, I've shared your company, I'm drinking your port wine in your armchair at your fireside. I've assumed the mantle of respectable Victorian English gentleman.
Doctor Edward Marlow, whose mantle you must continue to wear until the immediate crisis is behind us.
Crisis? Which particular crisis might that be? There are quite a few to choose from.

The crisis of losing our home, of being turned out into the street. This house is owned by an uncle of Edward's who has generously allowed us to live in it since our marriage. Edward has never been a man of independent means and the arrangement suited us well enough. It's always been understood, however, that if Edward dies, or is separated from his family for a year, the house will be sold from under us. My children and I will be left to fend for ourselves. Edward has not been home for almost a year.
I see. Hence your urgent need to find him.
Or else someone who looks like him.
Explain the situation to your husband's uncle, that Doctor Marlow was unwell before he left for Africa. He can't fail to be sympathetic.
Oh, I'm afraid he can. No love is lost between Edward and his uncle. He did not approve of our marriage. He makes no effort to see the children.
And yet he allows you to live in this house.
He allows Edward to live in this house. My children and I are here on his sufferance. If it were just for myself, I should not care. My concern is for Eddie and Henry.
What can I do to help?

Do exactly as you're doing. I know it is a pretence, a deception, possibly a criminal deception, but if the alternative is that we are to throw ourselves upon the mercy of the Parish and be torn apart, then I would choose deception a thousand times over. I shall not have my children taken from me. Please stay, even if it's just for a few days. Long enough for word to reach Uncle from other sources that Edward is alive and well, and in the
bosom of his family.
I'll stay. But where am I to sleep? Surely not
No, don't look so worried. There is a separate bedroom for you. Deceiving Edward's uncle is one thing, but being unfaithful to my husband is quite another.
Ow. Ah. Gone? What do you mean, gone?
What does the word normally mean, C'Rizz. Gone, as in departed, absent, missing, no longer here.
The Tardis has gone?
And the Doctor.
And Monsieur and Madame de Roche.
All gone?
All gone.
Yes.
I thought I'd found the Doctor, but this one turned out to be married.
Oh, can you imagine the Doctor being married? Pity his poor wife. Ow!
Hold still.
(tutting) I must say, sir, that the playbill illustration wasn't very flattering. You don't look quite so hideous in reality.
Thanks. Watch where you're putting your hands.
C'Rizz, will you please sit still?
Ow! It looks worse than it is, Charley. You should feel more sorry for Maxi. We could have forced him to come with us. Ow!
Yes, we could have, the way that Crackles forced you to do what he wanted?
The man's an absolute scoundrel. Deserves a damn good thrashing.
That was different.
Maxi may not think so. I mean, where would he go? Who'd look after him?
All right, you've made your point. But I feel bad about leaving him there.
Well, rest assured that the bounder will harm your friend at his own peril. In the meantime, we have more pressing concerns.
Like finding the Tardis and the Doctor. Ow!
Averting a revolution, young man. Preventing this great country from falling into the hands of the mob!
Right. Of course. What's he talking about?
Anarchy and chaos.
Oh, that.

The Duke is convinced that the disappearance of Monsieur and Madame de Roche will lead to public unrest. That people will think there's a plot by the aristocracy to keep the wealthy and titled in power, instead of sharing it amongst the whole of the population.
In a nutshell, m'dear. Couldn't have put it better meself. Ever thought of going into politics?
Well, as a matter of fact
We don't belong here, Charley. What difference does it make to us who's in power? And anyway, you know what happened in 1851, because it's
History?
It's okay. He knows. I told him.
Charley, you know that's not allowed. Oh, the Doctor'll
The Doctor has effectively kidnapped two people at a time when their presence may be most needed. There could be another French Revolution. The British Royal Family could be replaced by a President!
God forbid!
That's a bad thing?

I'm not saying it's good or bad. I'm saying it's not meant to happen that way. Well, certainly not according to my knowledge of events. But it may well happen if Monsieur de Roche and his wife are never seen again.
Which is where Miss Pollard comes in.
Oh, what have you done, Charley?
I haven't done anything. Well, not much. Just dressed up a bit, that's all.
She is Madame de Roche to the life. An amazing wig.
Thank you, Fazackerley. I think you've done with those bandages now.
Not quite finished yet, Your Grace. There's a bit to tuck in here.
Ouch!
Hands.
Yes, Charley has proved herself to be a very credible substitute for the missing Madame.
Merci beaucoup.
Yes, all we need now is someone who can substitute for the missing Monsieur.
Are you thinking what I'm thinking, Your Grace?
What's wrong? Charley? Why are you all looking at me?
Door creaks open.
Good morning, Georgina.
Door closes.
It promises to be another glorious summer's day.
I trust that you slept well?
Hardly at all, as it happens.
Oh?
Sleep is for tortoises, Georgina. I need very little of it to keep me going. But you look tired.
Edward's uncle has written in response to the letter which I sent to him yesterday.
And how is the old tyrant?
Here it is. You may wish to read it for yourself.

My dear Georgina, I must thank you for communication in informing me of my nephew's safe return to these shores. He has been much in my thoughts of late. As there is a small matter of business requiring my attention in town this afternoon, I have decided to combine this with a visit to your home to convey my regards to Edward in person. You may expect me at three o'clock precisely. Your uncle, Rufus Dimplesqueeze. Oh dear. You must write to him again, tell him not to come. Say that I've been struck down by a mysterious illness which was contracted in Africa.
It's too late for that, Doctor. He will already have left his home.
He mentions he has business in town. Send him a message there.
Uncle's business affairs are a closely guarded secret that he would certainly not entrust to me. I am afraid that we have no choice but to wait for three o'clock.
But Georgina, this changes everything. Now you'll have to tell him the truth.
Tell him what he wants to hear? No, Edward.
Doctor.
It changes nothing, Edward.
Horse's hooves.
I look utterly ridiculous.
Nonsense. You look absolutely delightful.
Stop moaning. Mister Fazackerley has worked wonders with your make-up and costume. So long as you keep concentrating on the right skin tones, no one would ever know you aren't human.
The clothes fit you so well that one might almost believe Monsieur de Roche and C'Rizz are twins. Two peas from the same pod. Oh, what say, Your Grace?
Fall back, Fazackerley, so I can pretend you're not there.
Yes, Your Grace.
Oh, this hairpiece is irritating my scalp. I want to rip it off.
Stop scratching your head. People will think you have lice. Leave it alone!
It's itching, Charley.
Madame de Roche.
Whatever.
Good day to you, sir.
Good day to you.
Madam.
Bonjour, monsieur. (sotto) You're supposed to say bonjour. You're French.
Eutermesan.
Today you're French.
Oh, no. What's he doing here?
Who?
Standing by that tree. Jacob Crackles.
He must be taking down his posters, now that the half-man, half beast that is Kerizo is gone.
It's not funny, Charley. I think he's seen me.
Oh, don't look, he's coming over.
Do something. Get rid of him.
What can I do? He'll probably recognise me as well.
Good day to you, sir.
Bonjour.
Don't I know you from somewheres?
(vaguely French) I don't think so. Please, go away.
S'il vous pla@t.
What?
Go away, s'il vous pla@t. (sotto) It's French.
Yes, go away, s'il vous pla@t. It's French.
Zis is Monsieur de Roche, and as you can see, I am Madame de Roche.
Are you sure? I'm very good with faces. I says to meself, I know these faces. Tell me I'm wrong.
He is quite sure, Mister Crackles. We meet again.
Oh, Duke.
You mean, Your Grace.
Oh, Your Grace, yeah. You with these two?
I am accompanying Monsieur and Madame de Roche, that is correct. What of it, sir?
Oh, nothing, nothing. Nothing, Your Grace. Nothing at all. I thought I'd seen their faces before. Ah. Must be wrong.
I think you must be, Mister Crackles. Good day to you. Don't forget about the Tower of London.
Oh! No, I won't, Your Grace. Good day.
Oh, that was close.
Too close. He's bound to suspect.
He knows, but he won't say anything, my boy. Not unless he wants me to carry out my threat.
This is starting to get a bit dangerous, Arthur.
Oh. Your Grace.
(laughs) Yes, I Know. Exciting, isn't it.
Clock ticking.
Please, Georgina, I can't do this. I don't want to be held responsible for losing the house, your home.

If anything goes wrong, Doctor, the responsibility for that is Edward's and mine. It was wrong of us to think that we could depend upon the goodwill of Uncle Rufus indefinitely. No blame will attach to anyone else.
I'd blame Edward. He should have made better provision for you and the children. He shouldn't have left you to cope with it all on your own.
I beg your pardon! What he should or shouldn't have done is quite frankly none of your business.
If I am to masquerade as your husband, then quite frankly it is my business.

I disagree. Perhaps Edward should have abandoned his research and accepted the position offered to him by his uncle. Perhaps we should have removed to a house that we could call our own. But we did not, and now we must face the consequences of having failed to act sooner.
What more proof is needed to convince your Uncle Rufus that we are husband and wife. We've just had our first row.
Oh. Oh, Doctor, I'm sorry.
Edward.
Yes, of course. Edward.
The clock plays Westminster chimes.
It's almost time.
Don't forget you were ill, that your memory was affected. It may be better to confine the conversation to safe subjects. The weather, for instance. Or the Great Exhibition.
The weather or the Great Exhibition. Right. Three o'clock on the dot. Here goes.
Your hands are shaking. I'll open the door.
How am I to address him? Uncle? Uncle Rufus? Sir? Mister Dimplesqueeze?
Uncle will do.
Opens door.
Georgina?
Please come in, Uncle. You're most welcome.
I should hope so, the journey I've had. Glad to get out of the heat for five minutes.
Door closes.
Where is he, then? Where's the wandering nephew?
Edward?
Hello, Uncle. How are you?
You've changed.
Pleasant weather, is it not.
No, it certainly isn't. Too hot for my liking. Can't bear too much heat. Never could.
The sunshine will probably attract more people to Hyde Park for the Great Exhibition.
What of it? I don't hold with public exhibitions. Frivolous extravagances that keep employees from their work. Can't bear public exhibitions. Never could.
I've prepared tea for you in the sitting room, Uncle. Would you like to step this way?
Wait a minute. Wait a minute.
Is something wrong?
I don't know. Perhaps. Where are the whiskers?
The whiskers?
You heard me, boy. The whiskers.
Still in Africa, Uncle.
Still in Africa, eh? (laughs) Still in Africa, he says. Still in Africa. I like that. Still in Africa. (laughs) Well done, well done.
Georgina and the Doctor laugh nervously.
Okay, brace yourself.
Yes.
You ready?
Yes
One, two, three!
Ow!
There you are. All done, all done.
Thanks. You won't catch me wearing that hairpiece again, revolution or no revolution. I don't care about Monsieur de Roche.

You'll care about him if he doesn't turn up and we're stuck in the nineteenth century for good. In the meantime, I'd rather be a French diplomat's wife than a prostitute or an exhibit in a freak show.
Who said anything about being a prostitute?
It's just a random example. The point is that we could be a lot worse off than living it up as guests of the Duke of Wellington. Three meals a day, comfortable bed, waited on hand and foot.
In return for which we have to dress up and pretend that we're other people. Well, I don't want these other lives any more. I don't want to be Monsieur de Roche or Kerizo the
half man, half beast. I want my own life back. I want to be plain old C'Rizz again.
You can be plain old C'Rizz again as soon as we find the Tardis.
As soon as the Tardis finds us, you mean.
Door creaks open.
Ah.
And the Crystal Palace is the most likely place for that to happen.
So what are we waiting for? Let's go there now.
Door creaks shut.
Tomorrow morning will be soon enough.
Arthur, why tomorrow morning?
Because that's when hundreds of other visitors to the Great Exhibition will expect to see you there. Well, not so much you and C'Rizz as a certain French diplomat and his wife.
Oh, no! I'm not putting that hairpiece back on.
You'll do as you're told, me boy. After the close shave at the Rotten Row this afternoon, it's clear that there needs to be a more public appearance by Monsieur de Roche.
Or no appearance at all. Why don't you just tell them that we've come down with the plague or something. That we're at death's door. They wouldn't want to see us then.

There's a lot more at stake than your lives if you don't show your faces again. It was my suggestion that the most suitable place to make such an appearance is the Glass Palace. The morning's first edition will therefore carry an announcement to that effect.
We'll be lynched.

I have every confidence in you, my dear. Very few people will have the temerity to question who you are. Most of those will be more interested in the Exhibition itself than in its visitors, French or otherwise. You'll be quite all right.
And if we're not? If something goes wrong?
My dear C'Rizz, I'm the Duke of Wellington. What could possibly go wrong?
A year is a long time, Edward.
Not quite a year, I think you'll find, Uncle.
Near enough, Georgina. Please don't interrupt. You must have thought about your family, your wife, your children. Damn it all, man, you must have known who you were.
My memory, I can't remember.
You found your way back to England. How does a man who has no memory of where he's come from manage to travel thousands of miles to find his way home, hmm? Tell me that.
It must have been a homing instinct, Uncle, like that of a messenger pigeon.
You would do well not to be facetious with me, boy.
In truth, Uncle, I have no recollection of it.
I found him, at the Glass Palace.
Found him at the Glass Palace, did you?
Edward happened to be there on one of my visits.
Looking for him, were you?
I had never stopped looking for him, Uncle.
Nothing to do with our little agreement, I suppose?
Out little agreement?
You know what I'm talking about, Georgina. Or have you lost your memory as well?
It seems odd that Edward has returned home just days before the first anniversary of his disappearance. Doesn't that seem odd to you?
I always knew that he'd return, Uncle. It was simply a question of when. I did not choose the moment.
Did you not? Another week of his prolonged absence and you would have been obliged to vacate this property under mutually agreed terms. You, and your children.
Yes, I have not forgotten.
But my nephew has returned. Fortune has indeed smiled upon you, Georgina. I'm happy for you.
Aren't you happy for yourself?
Edward, please.
Aren't you in the least bit concerned for the welfare of your nephew and his family? Your own flesh and blood?
I see that absence has sharpened your tongue, boy. This is a new side to you.
Would you like more tea, sir?

Perhaps it is you who should demonstrate proper concern for your wife and children. You who should give up your aimless travels and settle for the life that awaits you here. I can offer you a job worthy of your talents. A job which you'd be a fool to turn down again, Which will not be offered a third time. What say you?
You place me in a difficult position, Uncle.
Yes or no, Edward. The choice is yours.
Truly, Uncle, the choice is not mine alone. Georgina?
His travels mean a great deal to my husband. It is possible that rather than be separated from him, my children and I may decide to travel with him in future.
I see. In which event, you would have no further need of this house. Very well, that is your wish.
That is not what Georgina said.
Please, Doctor, you will only make matters worse.
Doctor? You're in the habit of addressing your husband as Doctor?
No, of course not.
I smell a rat.
You must allow me to explain, Uncle.
The only thing I require from you, Georgina, is a simple answer to a simple question. Is this man my nephew?
Georgina.
Answer me.
Why do you ask the question, Uncle? Do you not know your own nephew?
I sometimes wonder. But I am satisfied that it is he. Who else could it be? Welcome home, my boy.
Thank you, Uncle.
Come on, Maxi, you useless waste of space. We've got all the playbills, now we've got to get back and put on a show.
I'm going as fast as I can, Mister Crackles. My little legs. Two steps of mine to one of yours.
Yeah, not fast enough, though. Not with my star attraction gone and escaped.
With a bit of help, Mister Crackles, don't forget.
Yeah, yeah. And don't think I've forgot your part in that, neither. I've got a good memory, me. Tell me if I'm wrong.
Don't forget what the Duke said as well.
Now listen to me, Maxi. Listen good.
Maxi whimpers.

You do exactly what I say, Duke or no Duke. I ain't afraid of him, all right? By the weekend, we're away from this city and no Duke is gonna come a-looking for you, checking that you're being fed and watered all proper like. Do you understand? Do you understand?
Yeah, yeah, yes, Mister Crackles. Sorry, Mister Crackles.
Yeah, very good boy. Very good. Now then, I. Oh, for Gawd's sake, where did you come from?
Hello, Maxi. Still letting Jacob Crackles push you around?
C'Rizz, I never.
I told you, we need each other, him and me.
Really.
It was you, wasn't it. You. You and the girl dressed up like Frenchies.

How was it you sold me to the crowd? Half man, half beast? Will you ever, in your darkest nightmares, see anything so terrible, so miserable, so frightening. Believe me, Crackles, you've never in your darkest nightmares seen anything so frightening as me before.
Now, now, now, now, me friend.
I'm no friend of yours.
Now, what are you doing? What are you doing? Stay back. Stay back! Get away from me!
My friends told me that I should save you.
The Duke, you mean? And the pretty young girl?
No, Maxi. Other friends. You can't see them, but I can. There, and there. And I'm wondering if I should save you, Crackles, or just leave you here.
Leave me here. Oh, please, please, leave me here. Yeah, I'll stop the show, yeah. I'll give Maxi whatever he wants.
I don't believe you.
Don't hurt him. C'Rizz. Please. What would I do if he was gone?
It's all right. I'm not going to save him. I won't take him away. But I will do this.
roars
C'Rizz? Mister Crackles.
Maxi? Maxi, are you there?
Mister Crackles, you all right?
Yes. I can't move me legs. Why is it so dark?
Er, it's night time, Mister Crackles. But the moon is showing us the path home.
Moon? I can't see no moon, Maxi. I can't see nothing. Where's that creature?
He's gone. Like I said before, we need each other, you and me. Though I think you need me more than I need you.
I can't see. I can't move.
I'll take care of you, Mister Crackles. For now.
Horse drawn vehicle.
Many people appear to be drifting in the direction of the Glass Palace,
Your Grace.
The sun is shining, Fazackerley. What'd you expect?
It's us they want to see. The latest spectacle at the Great Exhibition. Charley and C'Rizz.
Monsieur and Madame de Roche. And as soon as they've seen you, they'll lose interest. They'll realise that it was a lot of fuss about nothing, mark my words.
This hairpiece isn't straight.
That's the best I could do after the savage way it had been removed. I am not a miracle worker, you know.
I can't face my public wearing a dodgy hairpiece.
(sotto) Can't be any worse than that thong.
Monsieur Christian and Madame Madeleine de Roche will today be making their final tour of the Great Exhibition before returning to Paris at the end of the week. I don't understand.
It's in this morning's first edition, Georgina. Don't you see?
No.
If Monsieur de Roche is able to visit the Great Exhibition today, then it can mean only one thing. That my ship has returned. The Tardis is back.
It means that you will be leaving us.

Put like that, I suppose it has two meanings, but they both mean the same thing to me. Freedom! I must go to the Glass Palace as soon as possible, just in case I miss them again. Will you come with me, Georgina?
On your travels?
To the Glass Palace.
Yes. Of course.
You have two young children, Georgina. Two very good reasons for staying. I'm sorry that I won't have a chance to meet Eddie and Henry.
Will you come and visit?
When my travels bring me in this direction, I'll certainly look in on you. At least your address won't have changed.
For a while longer, anyway, thanks in no small part to you, Doctor.
Stand aside, please, for Monsieur and Madame de Roche.
Everyone is staring at us like we're a couple of freaks.
Everyone is looking at you because you're a French diplomat and his wife. Don't be so paranoid.
I can't help it.
Just try to relax, C'Rizz. Pretend to take an interest in the Exhibition.
How's the hairpiece?
The hairpiece is fine.
Straight ahead, Monsieur de Roche. We're right behind you.
There it is, Georgina. The Glass Palace, where we first met. Where we must say goodbye.
Oh, let us say goodbye now, Doctor. I shall watch as you walk across the Park, away from me and out of our lives, back to your own life.
A part of me wants to stay.
A very small part, perhaps. The rest craves travel and adventure, far distant
places. You and Edward are much more alike than you realise.
Georgina, I
Please, go.
There is something, Georgina, and after all that's happened I hate to ask it of you.
Anything, Doctor. Ask of me what you will.
Could you lend me a shilling?
Charley, I think it's working. A few people are looking the other way. They're not bothered about us.
Of course. We're just another couple of visitors enjoying the Exhibition. Two people amongst thousands, most of whom wouldn't have recognised us anyway.
I really don't know what you were panicking about.
Oh, me panicking? I like that.
Neither of us existed at this time. One of us isn't even from this planet. If you think about if rationally, who on Earth would have the slightest idea that we're not who we appear to be?
Who's to say I'm not Madame Madeleine de Roche? Except maybe Madame Madeleine de Roche. My own mother wouldn't recognise me in this wig and make-up.
Charley?
Doctor?
Doctor?
C'Rizz?
Charley?
Your Grace!
Doctor.
Your Grace?
Fazackerley?
Mister Fazackerley.
Charley?
Doctor!
C'Rizz, is that really you?
Fazackerley, I think we need to make a strategic withdrawal from here as quickly as possible.
People are looking, Your Grace.
Oh dear, oh dear, oh dear, oh dear. Start circulating a story about using decoys to foil an assassination attempt, eh? Let's snatch victory from the jaws of defeat.
As usual, Your Grace.
I can't believe it's you, Doctor.
Believe me, Charley, the surprise is entirely mine.
We thought you'd left us here.
I didn't know what to think. Madame de Roche must have activated the Tardis by mistake.
I thought you were the only one who could operate the controls?
Anyone can operate the controls, if I've uncoupled the isomorphic circuit. As I did for you, C'Rizz, so that you could open the doors and use the scanner.
But if you're here, where's the Tardis?
Distant sound of the Tardis materialising.
Musical instruments!
I'll see you up there.
Oh, C'Rizz and I have to go, Your Grace. I hope you understand.
Of course I understand, m'dear. If I were a few years younger, I'd go with you.
Here you are, Fazackerley. (ripping sound.) I won't be needing this any more.
Goodbye, Charley. And good luck in the future.
Goodbye, Arthur.
Footsteps run away.
Fazackerley.
I said nothing, Your Grace.
Yeah, but you were thinking it, huh? Huh? (laughs)
Tardis door opens.
Is it safe to come out now, Docteur?
Quite safe, Madame. The assassin's long gone.
Oh, very good. You ‘ave a wonderful machine, if I may say so.
You must let us know if you ever change your mind about selling it.
I couldn't possibly put a price on the Tardis, Monsieur. It's my home. Complete with temporal drift compensators that appear to be on the blink.
Everything ‘as it's price, Docteur.
The Duke of Wellington has been looking for you. I believe that you're needed downstairs rather urgently.
Allez-y, Christian. We mustn't keep the Duke waiting. Au revoir, Docteur.
Au revoir, and be careful that you don't bump into anything on the way. You might set it off my accident.
What are those two looking at?
Probably you, C'Rizz.
Me?
You've put a bit of weight on since I last saw you, Charley.
Oh! Be off with you, my good man. You have a lot of explaining to do.
Oh dear.
Well, C'Rizz, that was 1851.
Mmm. Freakish.
Tardis door closes. The Tardis dematerialises.
The band finishes playing Lillibullero to a smattering of applause.
Georgina.
Edward?
Oh, my darling Georgina! I knew you'd find me if I waited long enough.
Edward! Edward!
Who else? My darling, I've come home.
It is you.
Of course. Have I changed so much?
You haven't changed at all, Edward. But the beard will have to go.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
DOCTOR: What can she possibly have done to harm you? Leave her alone!
GRISWALD: I'm warning you, Doctor. Don't make me do it.
DOCTOR: Georgina has no part in this, Griswald.
GRISWALD: She's your wife, isn't she?
DOCTOR: No, she isn't.
GRISWALD: Oh, you're lying. She's your wife, which means she's in it up to her neck.
DOCTOR: What do you want?
GRISWALD: I knew you were a toff. Nice big house in a nice part of town. Must have plenty of money stashed away.
DOCTOR: You're wrong. There is no money.
GRISWALD: I didn't get paid by the Frenchies. I didn't deliver the goods, thanks to you. So I reckon it's only fair that you pay me what I'm owed.
DOCTOR: This is between you and me, Griswald. Let Georgina go and I'll see what I can do.
GRISWALD: Yeah. And you'll do nothing. This poor, defenceless woman is my guarantee that you'll do exactly what I say.
DOCTOR: Be reasonable. How do you expect me to find money in the middle of Hyde Park?
GRISWALD: You'll find it if you have to.
DOCTOR: Perhaps the Police Constable standing behind you could help?
GRISWALD: Oh no, Doctor. I'm not falling for that one. The moment I turn to look behind me, you'll make your move and I'll be done for. You must think I'm a fool.
DOCTOR: The thought had crossed my mind.
GEORGINA: Oh, Edward. He grabbed me. I didn't know what to do.
DOCTOR: It's all right, you're safe now. Thank you, Constable.
CONSTABLE: Right you are, sir.
DOCTOR: We'll leave Mister Griswald in your capable hands. Come on, Georgina. I'd better take you home.
WELLINGTON: Well, Fazackerley, the trade bill said Piccadilly Circus. Have you found the right freak show?
FAZACKERLEY: I believe I have, Your Grace. Owned and run by a Mister Jacob Crackles. A short walk from where we are now.
CHARLEY: Did you see C'Rizz?
FAZACKERLEY: Despite the darkness, I felt it imprudent to loiter for long, in case my interest should, ahem, arouse suspicion.
WELLINGTON: You'd better be right about this, Charley. We'll make complete fools of ourselves if you're not.
CHARLEY: Trust me, Arthur.
FAZACKERLEY: Oh, how many more times! It's Your Grace.
WELLINGTON: Oh, shut up, Fazackerley.
JACOB: And now, ladies and gentlemen, be horrified, be amazed. Ladies and gentlemen, for your education, enlightenment and edification, Jacob Crackles is proud to present to you the half man, half beast that is Kerizo!
JACOB: It's all right, ladies and gentlemen. Do not be alarmed. Those chains are very
JACOB: strong. Very, very strong indeed. He can't hurt you. Consider the wretched life of a creature whose body is a twisted parody of the human form. Will you ever, in your darkest nightmares, see anything so
WELLINGTON: Stop what you are doing, sir! Stop it at once, I say. This is intolerable.
JACOB: Who are you, sir, who presumes to interrupt a man in the conduct of his legitimate business?
WELLINGTON: I, sir, am the Duke of Wellington.
WELLINGTON: And you, sir, will do as you're told.
CHARLEY: Hello, C'Rizz.
C'RIZZ: Charley! Oh my God, Charley, I thought I'd never see you again. What are you doing here? Where's the Doctor?
CHARLEY: Here, put this cloak on.
WELLINGTON: Keys, Fazackerley, keys on his belt.
FAZACKERLEY: Yes, Your Grace.
JACOB: Don't touch those keys. This is an outrage! You have no right.
WELLINGTON: Hold your tongue, showman, or I'll run you through where you stand! Do I make myself clear?
CHARLEY: Those are marks from a whip, C'Rizz. Has he been beating you?
C'RIZZ: Don't worry about it. Maxi's in the cage behind. You have to let him out.
CHARLEY: Let's get you out of these chains first.
JACOB: I'll take it further. I'll take it to the highest authority in the land.
WELLINGTON: Oh? Jacob Crackles versus the Duke of Wellington. I don't think so, Crackles. I fought Napol@on Bonaparte twice, and believe me, sir, you do not even remotely compare with Napol@on Bonaparte.
C'RIZZ: Oh, that's better.
CHARLEY: Open the cage please, Mister Fazackerley.
FAZACKERLEY: I know, I know.
C'RIZZ: So, where's the Doctor?
CHARLEY: I'll tell you later. We should get away from this place as quickly as possible.
C'RIZZ: Give me that sword and I'll deal with him.
JACOB: Don't give him the sword. He'll kill me! He's a maniac! Look, tell me if I'm wrong.
WELLINGTON: There'll be no bloodshed tonight. Not unless you provoke me, Crackles.
JACOB: I won't provoke you, sir. I won't provoke you.
C'RIZZ: Maxi!
MAXI: C'Rizz, what's happening?
C'RIZZ: You're coming with us.
MAXI: I can't, C'Rizz.
C'RIZZ: Of course you can. Come on. We don't have time to argue about it.
MAXI: There's no argument, C'Rizz. Let me stay, please. Try to understand. This is my life. This is how it has to be.
FAZACKERLEY: We really must go, Miss Pollard.
CHARLEY: Yes, thank you, Mister Fazackerley, we'll be with you in a moment. C'Rizz!
C'RIZZ: Will you be all right with Crackles?
MAXI: I can manage him. Now go.
C'RIZZ: Let's go, Charley.
CHARLEY: Your Grace!
WELLINGTON: I'll be keeping an eye on you, Crackles. The least sign of trouble and I shall make it my personal duty to ensure that you spend what remains of your misbegotten life in the Tower of London. Is that clear?
JACOB: Yes.
CHARLEY: Arthur, come on.
WELLINGTON: I'll keep it ready for you, Crackles.
MAXI: Mister Crackles? That man looked just like the Duke of Wellington. Mister Crackles?
DOCTOR: Tell me if you'd prefer to be alone.
GEORGINA: No, of course not, Edward. Come in. There's a glass of port wine at the side of the armchair for you.
DOCTOR: Thank you, just the thing. You're very thoughtful. What's that you're working on?
GEORGINA: My needlepoint. It's a kneeler for the church. Nothing very extraordinary, I'm afraid, but I promised it to the vicar some months ago. Perhaps you'd like to read the newspaper?
DOCTOR: Hmm. I can find out what's been happening at the Great Exhibition.
GEORGINA: We know only too well what's been happening at the Great Exhibition., or at least in Hyde Park.
DOCTOR: Not quite what I meant. Are you sure you're all right, Georgina? You've recovered amazingly well from the attack.
GEORGINA: I should be angry with you.
DOCTOR: Yes, you should.
GEORGINA: I should be absolutely furious with you.
DOCTOR: You aren't?
GEORGINA: We're alive, aren't we? No lasting harm has been done. The man is back behind bars where he belongs.
DOCTOR: I'm glad you're not angry.
GEORGINA: It has to be said, Edward, that you do seem to be keeping dangerous company nowadays. I'm not prepared to allow the children to be exposed to such danger.
DOCTOR: Believe me, Georgina, I would not wish any harm to come to them. You must know that. Nor to you.
GEORGINA: Does the newspaper say anything of interest about the Exhibition?
DOCTOR: Er, descriptions of the newest exhibits, background information about some of the exhibitors. Ah, here we are. Listen to this. It is to be hoped that the French representatives of Louis-Napol@on will find time in their busy itinerary to favour the exhibition with a second visit before returning to Paris later this week. An air of mystery surrounds the present whereabouts in London of Monsieur and Madame de Roche, who have thus far been guests of the Duke of Wellington at Apsley House, although it is expected this will be dispelled by their imminent reappearance. Are you all right, Georgina?
GEORGINA: Yes, thank you. Quite all right. My eyes are rather tired.
DOCTOR: You're straining them with that needlepoint. If you have spectacles, you should wear them. Do you wear spectacles?
GEORGINA: No, I don't. But Edward does.
DOCTOR: Does he.
GEORGINA: Yes, he does. He would have great difficulty reading such minuscule
GEORGINA: newspaper print without them. Unlike you, who seem to have no difficulty at all.
